title: WebLogic - Overview
description:
## WebLogic

This dashboard displays key throughput and activity metrics for your WebLogic infrastructure and helps you correlate WebLogic performance with infrastructure resources. This dashboard provides a high-level overview of your WebLogic infrastructure at a quick glance. For further reading on WebLogic:

* [Datadog's WebLogic integration docs](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/weblogic/)
* [WebLogic docs](https://docs.oracle.com/en/middleware/fusion-middleware/weblogic-server/index.html)
* [How to configure JMX Remote Monitoring in WebLogic](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdenl)
* [Information on Datadog's JMX configuration](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/java/)

Clone this template dashboard to make changes and add your own graph widgets.

definition.content: Using this dashboard, you can get a high-level view of your WebLogic Server activity, including performance and thread pool utilization.

**For more information on setup and monitoring, check out the following**

- [WebLogic Integration docs â†—](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/weblogic/)
- [WebLogic Server Docs](https://docs.oracle.com/en/middleware/fusion-middleware/weblogic-server/index.html)
- [How to configure JMX Remote Monitoring in WebLogic](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/management/agent.html#gdenl)
- [Information on Datadog's JMX configuration](https://docs.datadoghq.com/integrations/java/?tab=host)
The mean number of requests completed per second.

Queue length refers to the number of pending requests in the priority queue. It is the total of internal system requests and user requests. 

Maximum Shared Capacity refers to the maximum amount of requests that can be accepted in the priority queue.
The number of completed requests in the priority queue.

definition.title: Open Sockets vs Max Open Sockets
Top Stuck Threads by Application Runtime
Active Execute Threads vs Total Execute Threads

definition.content: By comparing Active vs Total Execute Threads, you can see how many threads are performing work.
Idle and Standby Threads are available for performing work

Hogging threads and Stuck threads are important to monitor as they are unable to perform new work until the current work is completed. Hogging threads may become Stuck after meeting any stuck constraints. These should be carefully monitored.
